intro: Stenogyne nelsonii, commonly known as Nelson's false geranium, is a flowering plant native to the Hawaiian Islands. It belongs to the mint family, Lamiaceae, and is characterized by its small, showy flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded habitats such as forests and streamside areas. It has opposite, ovate leaves with hairy surfaces and produces small, four-lobed fruits. Stenogyne nelsonii is considered a rare and endangered species, highlighting the importance of conservation efforts in its native habitat.
